A análise detalhada da arquitetura destes depósitos revela significativas variações

na geometria, com características consideravelmente mais complexas do que aquelas de

lençóis de areia simples, Iateralmente extensos e empilhaclos previsto pela maioria dos

modelos deposicionais existentes para sistemas fluviais pré-vegetação . Estes resultados
sugerem que o estilo entrelaçado-enr-lençol na verdade cnglobam um número variado de

diferentes estilos pré-vegetação (Santos et a\.,2011b) . AIém disso, este estudo demonstra

que sistemas fluviais axiais e transversais podem ser preservados ern urì tnesûro cettário

tectônico e climático.

3.2. ARflGO lz DISTINCT STYLES OF AAMBRIAN FLUVIAL
DEPOSTTTON 44



Sedimentology (2074) 61, 881-914 doi: 10.1111/sed.'t 2o7 q

Distinct styles of fluvial deposition in a Cambrian rift basin
MAURICIO G. M. SANTOS*T, RENATO p. ALMEIDA*, LUCAS p. S. GODINHO*,
ANDRÉ MARCONATO* and NIGEL p. MOUNTNEYT
*Instituto de Geocièncias, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua do Lago 562, Cidade ILnivercitâria,
CEP 05508-080, São PauÌo, SP, Brazil (E-mail: mauriciogmsantos@gmailcom)
tFluvial Research Group, Earth Sciences School of Earth and Environment, [Jniversity of Leeds,
Leeds, LSz 9JT, West Yorkshirc, UK

ABSTRACT

Process-based and facies models to account for the origin of pre-vegetation (i.e.
pre-Silurian) preserved fluvial sedimentary architectures remain poorly
defined in terms of their ability to account for the nature of the fluvial
conditions required to accumulate and preserve architectural elements in the
absence ofthe stabilizing influence ofvegetation. In pre-vegetation fluvial suc-
cessions, the repeated reworking of bars and minor channels that resulted in
the generation and preservation of broad, tabular, stacked sandstone-sheets
has been previously regarded as the dominant sedimentary mechanism. This
situation is closely analogous to modern-day poorly vegetated systems deve-
loped in arid climatic settings. However, this study demonstrates the wide-
spread presence of substantially more complex stratigraphic architectures.
The Guarda Velha Formation of Southern Brazil is a >500 m-thick synrift flu-
vial succession of Cambrian age that records the deposits and sedimentary
architecture of three distinct fluvial successions: (i) an early rift-stage system
characterized by coarse-grained channel elements indicative of a distributive
pattern with flow transverse to the basin axis; and two coeval systems from the
early- to climax-rift stages that represent (ii) an axially directed, trunk fluvial
system characterized by large-scale amalgamated sandy braid-bar elements,
and (iii) a distributive fluvial system characterized by multi-storey, sandy
braided-channel elements that flowed transverse to the basin axis. Integration
of facies and architectural-element analysis with regional stratigraphic basin
analysis, palaeocurrent and pebble-provenance analysis demonstrates the
mechanisms responsible for preserving the varied range of fluvial architectures
present in this pre-vegetation, rift-basin setting. Identified major controls that
influenced pre-vegetation fluvial sedimentary style include: (i) spatial and
temporal variation in discharge regime; (ii) the varying sedimentological char-
acteristics of distinct catchment areas; (iii) the role of tectonic basin
configuration and its direct role in influencing palaeoflow direction and fluvial
style, whereby both the axial and transverse fluvial systems undertook a dis-
tinctive response to syn-depositional movement on basin-bounding faults.
Detailed architectural analyses of these deposits reveal significant variations
in geometry, with characteristics considerably more complex than that of sim-
ple, laterally extensive, stacked sandstone-sheets predicted by most existing
depositional models for pre-vegetation fluvial systems. These results suggest
that the sheet-braided style actually encompasses a varied number of different
pre-vegetation fluvial styles. Moreover, this study demonstrates that contem-
poraneous axial and transverse fluvial systems with distinctive architectural
expressions can be preserved in the same overall tectonic and climatic setting.

Keywords Axial fluvial systems, pre-vegetation, Camaquã Basin, Cambrian,
depositional architecture, distributive fluvial systems, pre-vegetation, rift
basin.

INTRODUCTION

The interpretation of fluvial successions
preserved in the rock record typically relies on
the analysis of depositional features that are not
necessarily diagnostic of any specific deposi-
tional setting and the reconstruction of fluvial
system type from preserved successions is
therefore typically not straightforward. The
concept of a continental rock record that is
dominated by the preserved deposits of distri-
butive fluvial systems has gained favour in
recent years based largely on studies that rely
on remotely sensed imagory from modorn-day
depositional systems (e.g. Hartley et al., 2O1Oa,
b; Weissmann et al., 2010), although also
supported by detailed studies of ancient fluvial
successions (e.g. Nichols & Fisher, 2007; Fisher
et al., 2008; Cain & Mountney, 2009, 2071").
Considerable discussion exists in the published
literature regarding the mechanisms by which
predominant fluvial styles may become prefer-
entially preserved in the rock record (Sambrook
Smith et ol., 2o7o; Fielding et al., 2o1,2). How-
ever, to date little work has been undertaken to
apply these concepts to pre-vegetation alluvial
systems. This study describes the sedimentology
and stratigraphic evolution of a Cambrian
fluvial succession that was oriented transverse
to the axis of an evolving rift basin; further, this
study considers the style of interaction of this
transverse system with a contemporaneously
active, axially directed fluvial system. The two
preserved fluvial successions have markedly
different sedimentological expressions, despite
both having developed under the influence of
the same set of basin controls and experiencing
similar climatic regimes.

Many pre-vegetation fluvial successions are
characterized by preserved sedimentary expres-
sions that mimic those of present-day systems
developed under the influence of arid or semi-
arid climatic regimes (Long, 2006). Two main
depositional styles are common in pre-vegeta-
tion fluvial successions: braided fluvial architec-
tures with compound-bar elements and fluvial
architectures dominated by bedload-sheet
elements. These two contrasting sedimentary
styles are commonly considered to have arisen
as a consequence of fluvial system development
under the influence of different climatic settings,
reflecting perennial and ephemeral flow, respec-
tively (e.g. Eriksson et al., ').998,2006; Tirsgaard
& Øxnevad, 1998). Existing facies models for

such pre-vegetation fluvial systems (e.g. Cotter,
1978; Long, 1978, 2OO6, 2O77; Eriksson ef a/.,
1998, 2006; Sønderholm & Tirsgaard, 1998;
Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998) are not necessarily
effective as tools with which to account for
observed palaeoenvironmental characteristics
because they do not provide a generically appli-
cable methodology with which to account for
climatic signatures.

This study describes a >500 m-thick fluvial
succession deposited in a continental rift-basin
of Cambrian age in Southern Brazil, The research
was conducted through the integration of high-
resolution depositional facies and architectural-
element analysis, in combination with pebble-
provenance and palaeocurrent analysis, and
supported by the erection of a regional tectono-
stratigraphic framework. Specific objectives are
as follows: (i) to study different architectural ele-
ments and their association with various types of
primary fluvial forms, including channels, bars,
dunes and sheets; (ii) to investigate the relations
between preserved fluvial architecture, sediment
provenance and palaeogeographic location
within an evolving rift basin; (iii) to examine the
relative roles played by autogenic and allogenic
controls; (iv) to characterize depositional styles
and fluvial palaeoenvironments in a pre-vegeta-
tion, synrift alluvial-plain succession; (v) to pro-
pose models with which to explain how fluvial
styles can be preserved for pre-vegetation sys-
tems; and (vi) to provide a predictive facies
model with which to better understand pre-
Silurian (i.e, pre-vegetation) systems.

This work is significant for the following
reasons: (i) it provides a specific case-study for
the interpretation of depositional architecture
from a pre-vegetation fluvial succession; (ii) it
identifies how local environmental factors act to
control the preserved architecture of such sys-
tems; (iii) it demonstrates the style of interplay
between contemporaneously active axial and
transverse fluvial systems; (iv) it outlines a
method by which an improved understanding of
the particular characteristics of such systems
can be better understood.

PRE.VEGETATION FLUVIAL SYSTEMS

The absence of land plants prior to the Silurian
resulted in the development of distinctive types
of fluvial environments, many of which were

indicative of a fluvial system that experienced
perennial or at least semi-perennial (intermittent)
flow (cf. Miall, 1996; Long, 2006). The accumu-
lation of this large river system, with a markedly

different palaeocurrent flow direction from that
of the underlying rift-initiation deposits, proba-
bly reflects the capture of an existing river sys-
tem that flowed outside the confines of the
basin during the early-rift stage (cf. Gawthorpe
& Leeder, 2000). The mechanism for this capture
might have arisen as a consequence of ongoing
subsidence leading to an increase of gradient in
a direction towards the main basin depocentre,
with this fluvial system constantly migrating or
avulsing towards the maximum-subsidence
areas (e.g. Leeder & Gawthorpe, 1,987; Peakall,
1998).

Fluvial forms record a tendency of bars to
develop upwardly from lateral- to downstream-
accretion, a pattern described elsewhere by
Bridge (2003), and which would be expected in
longitudinal sections wherever a braid-bar
shows both downstream accretion and some
degree of lateral expansion. Smaller-scale bed-
forms, such as minor-scours, which are charac-
terized by relatively widely dispersed
palaeocurrent distributions, probably reflect the
presence of bar-chute and bar-top channels (Bri-
stow, 1993). By contrast, larger-scale forms are
characterized by relatively uniform and unimo-

Fig, 4. Palaeocurrent data recorded
by this study for the three studied
fluvial systems: Early-Rift Fluvial
System; Early to Climax-Rift

(Transverse system),

dal trends of palaeocurrent data. Analyses inte-
grating the complete set of palaeocurrent data,
together with bounding-surface data, reveal a
predominantly downstream pattern of bedform
migration, showing vector mean dip direction
towards 158o for bounding surfaces (n: 722)
and 1B7o for cross-strata (n = 183).

The combined interpretation of outcrops
shows mean palaeocurrent vectors with similar
trends, but a contrasting dispersion of palaeo-
current directional data. For example, the
presence of scour and fill structures (Fig. 11,A'),
as well as the occurrence of small-scale sets of
trough cross-stratification, corroborates the idea
of a more complex arrangement of bar-top
channels for this succession in relation to that
of the panel depicted in Fig. 118. This diffe-
rence may be due to variation in the preserva-
tion of the upper part of the bars due to
different flow regimes as a consequence of
variations in fluvial discharge related to differ-
ent rates of precipitation. The presence of con-
cave-up fifth-order surfaces (for example,
Fig. 12) suggests considerable channelization,
probably induced by the confined palaeogeo-
graphic setting of this system determined by the

@ 2013 The Authors, Journal compilation @ 2013 Intornational Association of Sedimentologists, Sedimentology, 61, 881-914



59

basin margin to the west and the transverse flu-
vial system (see below) to the east.

It seems that the fluvial-fan system located
close to the eastern margin of the basin (related
to the Early-Rift Fluvial System described previ-
ously and the Transverse Fluvial System
described below) was directly eroded by the
large-scale, axial fluvial system. It is likely that
the erosion of this fan system inhibited the
development of more extensive and more
complex fan-systems emanating from the eastern
part of the basin, principally because the rate of
water discharge and sediment supply from the

FIuviaI sedimentation in a Cambrian rift basin B9S
northerly source was sufficiently great to
overwhelm sediment being delivered by the
system flowing from the east,

Transverse Fluvial System
Description; A typical vertical succession show-
ing the style of stacking of lithofacies present in
deposits of the eastern part of the study region is
illustrated in Fig. 7C. This system preserves a
more varied occurrence of facies associations
than that of the previously described axial
system. Not only do sets and cosets of trough
cross-stratified, medium to pebbly sandstone

Deformation structures indicative of syn-depo-
sitional liquidization processes (Allen, 1984) in
the Guarda Velha Formation are present in fine-
sandstone or pebbly-sandstone facies but such
features do not occur in mudstone facies. Such
structures include water-escape cusps, recum-
bent-folded cross-stratification, synclines, anti-
clines, disharmonic folds, eye-shaped folds and
dewatering pipes. None of these structures are
apparently related to any particular bedform
type or fluvial form. There is no evidence of
slumps or deformation related to heterolithic
features. The size of liquefaction features ranges
from centimetre-scale (open folds restricted to
individual sets and with associated water-
escape structures) to metre-scale (overturned

Some examples of laterally extensive deforma-

alternation between trough cross-stratified sets
presenting overturned cross-stratification and
non-deformed foresets.

Details of the varied range of depositional
architectures present in this system are provided
in Table 2, and include the presence of elements
indicative of the development of scour-fiIl, the
accumulation of fine-grained overbank deposits,
abandoned channels, downstream accretion and
the common alternation between sandy bedforms
and laminated sand sheets. Depositional architec-
ture is characterized by the dominance of sandy
bedforms, alternating with laminated sand sheets
(Fig. 13), abandoned-scours (Fig. 13), overbank-

Interpretation; Analysis of data collected from
the eastern part of the study region reveals the
deposits of a fluvial system originated from a
basin-border region with a radial pattern of pal-
aeocurrents recording flow that was transverse
to the elongate axis of the basin and towards the
main depocentre, similar to those interpreted in
the literature as distributive fluvial systems (e.g.
Hartley et al. 2o7oa, Weissmann et al., 2O7O).
Provenance analysis demonstrates a sediment
source area related to the bedrock lithologies
currently present at the eastern margin of the
basin, revealing no relative lateral displacement
of the basin during or following accumulation.

ous belt of debris-flow-dominated alluvial-fan
deposits with basinward-directed palaeocur-
rents originating from a NNE-striking fault
region (Paim, 1994, 1995; Almeida et al., 2OO9),
probably resulted in the development of a flu-
vial-fan system, of which the distributive flu-
vial system studied here is interpreted to
represent the distal part, Importantly, such flu-
vial fans reworked sediments delivered by the
debris-flow-dominated fans. Moreover, the
transverse orientation of the mean palaeocur-
rent direction relative to that of the axial
fluvial system denotes a contributory character
for this particular sub-system that enables it to
be distinguished from the axial fluvial system,
implying that the transverse river system
drained into the axial trunk river. This situa-
tion, together with the basinward grain-size fin-
ing described by Paim (1995), suggests a basin-
wide overall downslope gradient towards the
western part of the basin. Provenance analysis
indicates that metamorphic and granitic base-
ment regions with limited areal extent lying
adjacent to the eastern margin of the basin
acted as source areas to these sediments, simi-
lar to the previously described early-rift fluvial
system; sediment source repeatedly varied
through time from distal to proximal.

Accumulation and preservation of sigmoidal-
stratified sets occurs under conditions transi-
tional between the dune and plane-bed stability
fields (Fielding, 2006). Pebbly sandstones with
normally graded foresets are interpreted as con-
glomeratic unit bars with angle-of-repose formed
by the avalanching of particles previously sorted
in superposed bedforms (McConnico & Bassett,
2OO7). Preserved mean set thickness suggests
that water depth for this fluvial system was shal-
lower than that of the axial fluvial system, as
would be expected for a contributory system;
the ability of this system to avulse coupled with
its relatively unconfined setting (in comparison
with that of the axial system) would also have
facilitated channel widening allowing the fluvial
system to occupy broader areas.

The cyclic intercalation between bodies of
trough and planar cross-bedded sets of varied
thickness that are commonly eroded in their
upper part by sets of plane-parallel-laminated
sandstone is interpreted to reflect high variation
in discharge (Miall, 1984). The presence of var-
ied facies associations, including mud lenses
and rippled sandstone also supports the inter-
pretation of a fluvial system subject to consider-
able discharge variation. The local occurrence of
mud flakes implies that mud deposits were dried
and then eroded, and in this way such features
are indicative of sub-aerial exposure soon-after
succeeded by flow characterized by traction cur-
rents (cf. Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998). Mud
lenses, minor-scale bedforms and mudcracks are
interpreted in Fig. 17. Some laterally extensive
laminated sand-sheet elements characterized by
planar erosional surfaces cutting a series of
fluvial forms (Fig. 10G) might record floods from
the axial system that occurred at a time when
the distal alluvial plain of the contributory
(transverse) system acted as the floodplain to the
main axial system, resulting in toe-cutting ero-
sion processes (cf. Leeder & Mack, 2001), or
alternatively floods originating in the uplands
to the east, with reworking and erosion of the
un-vegetated river-banks. This type of erosion
therefore could record the lateral erosion of baj-
ada-forming alluvial systems by river channels
directed along the main basin axis. The style of
preservation of a transverse river system drain-
ing into an axial trunk river system demon-
strates not only the evolution of the fluvial
system on the hangingwall of a half-graben but
also the evolution of the early-rift system (rift-
initiation stage) into a mature through-going
basin (through-going-rift) with a well-developed
bajada system along its eastern margin (cf. Gaw-
thorpe & Leeder, 2000).

The common occurrence of scour-fill elements
(Fie. 15), together with large sandy-bedform
elements preserving concave-up lower surfaces,
is indicative of a system in which channels were
widely developed. The actual size of the main

channel elements is not clearly recognizable
because they are laterally more extensive than the
studied outcrops; however, examination of the
more extensive outcrops reveals numerous major
erosional surfaces incising a series of older
deposits (Fig. 16). Channel incisions are probably
related to proximal parts of fluvial systems, lead-
ing to the amalgamation of channel forms (cf.
Nichols & Fisher, 2007; Cain & Mountney, 2009),
The transverse-system deposits preserve highly
amalgamated channel forms, which are inter-
preted to have accumulated as the result of high
rates of channel avulsion, a situation probably
enhanced by the non-cohesive (and non-
vegetated) nature of thu uhauuel l-rauks. This
probably resulted in the generation and preserva-
tion of laterally extensive sandbodies, which are
many tens to hundreds of metres wide, indicating
the likely occurrence of preserved channel ele-
ments with high width-to-thickness ratios
(Gibling, 2006). Infened fifth-order bounding sur-
faces (Miall, 1985; Fig. 16) confirm that channel
forms were indeed laterally extensive; preserved
channel elements are 10 to 20 m thick and
>200 m wide. According to the methodology pro-
posed by Gibling (2006), the data presented
herein are indicative of medium-width channels
characterized by narrow to broad sheets, demon-
strating that this system was characteristically
poorly confined.

Facies analysis of soft-sediment deformed
strata reveals no relation between liquefaction
structures and bedform type, set thickness or
grain size; thus, the deformation features occur
in an apparently random distribution. This sit-
uation, combined with the similarity of the
studied structures with laboratory features
which were triggered by seismic-shaking
(Owen, 1996; Moretli et al., 1999), suggests that
these structures are likely to have been trig-
gered by seismic activity (Santos & Almeida,
2oIo; Santos et al., 201.2). This would be
expected in a tectonically active basin,
particularly during the climax rift stage, during
which tectonic activity would have been
heightened (Prosser, 1993). For an autokinetic

(process-based) mechanism to have served as
the trigger for liquidization, a direct relation
between facies and architectural elements and
deformation structures would be expected
(Leeder, 1987), Overturned cross-stratification
reveals liquefaction events that occurred simul-
taneous to current shear-drag (Allen & Banks,
7972), revealing a relation between river-flow
activity and liquidization, The near-rhythmic
alternation between sets preserving overturned
cross-stratification and non-deformed sets
suggests constant flow because the coincidence
of river-flow activity and seismic-events is very
unlikely to have been repeatedly recorded had
the fluvial system not experienced perennial
flow (Santos et a1.,2072),

Interpretation of the Early- to Climax-Rift-
Stage Fluvial Systems

The Guarda Velha Formation records the deve-
lopment of a complex arrangement of fluvial
deposits that collectively demonstrate the coeval
development of an alluvial plain comprising
two laterally interacting fluvial systems: an axial
river characterized by a channel belt indicative
of a braided fluvial system that flowed from
north to south and a transverse, contributory
distributive fluvial system that flowed from east
to west. A large catchment area north of the
basin is interpreted from the scale of the pre-
served bedforms, together with palaeocurrent
and pebble provenance analysis. The main dif-
ference between eastern and northern sources is
the presence of a belt of quartz mylonites and
mylonitic granites next to the eastern basin bor-
der and trending parallel to the basin. Granites
and rhyolites occur in all areas surrounding the
basin. Given the restricted occurrence of these
mylonites to the first few kilometres to the east
of the basin, the abundance of such clast types
in the t¡ansverse system (always more than
25%) suggests a greater contribution of local
sources than is observed in the axial system,
which is richer in reworked vein quartz, Since
the transverse system was contributory to the

axial one, mylonites Íue also found in the lat-
ter, and are notably more abundant down-
stream of the area of the inferred confluence of
the two systems. Apart from this marked differ-
ence in proportion of clasts from an identifi-
able source, some clast types found in the
axial system seem to be absent from the trans-
verse one: notably, sandstones from older units
of the Camaquã Basin are composed, in part, of
detrital minerals and clasts of aplite, and low-
grade metasediment, sources of which crop out
in the alea west of the basin, suggesting trans-
port to the axial system via debris-flow related
alluvial fans identified in the western border
area.

The area of occurrence of the Guarda Velha
Formation supports the interpretation of a
basin-wide intra-rift fluvial plain that, accord-
ing to the variation and spatial distribution of
facies associations, accommodated a complex
fluvial system in which the two recognized
fluvial-system types were characterized by con-
trasting patterns of channels and hydraulic
regimes. These were due, in part, to their dif-
ferent catchment areas (identified through
provenance analysis - Fig. 5 - which revealed
different sediment sources), their different set-
tings within the evolving rift basin (rift axis
versus hangingwall rift-basin margin) and their
style of lateral inter-fingering. The basinal-scale
development of the hangingwall fluvial and
alluvial fans to the east apparently forced the
axial river system to the footwall side of the
basin, a situation typical of asymmetrical rifts
(e.g. Leeder & Gawthorpe, 1987; Peakall, tggA;
Gawthorpe & Leeder, 2000), Indeed, the depos-
its of the eastern basin margin were able to
develop fluvial-dominated streams, whereas the
deposits of the western basin margin were fed
by proximal sources, and were rapidly
reworked by the major, southerly flowing axial
system. This situation is similar to those
described by Gawthorpe & Leeder (2000),
where hangingwall-sourced alluvial fans typi-
cally present larger dimensions than footwall-
sourced fans. These results collectively suggest
that, although both basin borders were active,
the western fault represents the main syn-sedi-
mentary basin border fault that gave rise to a
basin asymmetry with the western part of the
basin experiencing higher subsidence rates.

There exists an overall upward-decrease in
grain size throughout the Guarda Velha Forma-
tion, from the early-rift fluvial system with its
conglomeratic bars, passing upward through the

Fluvial sedimentation in a Cambrian rift basin 909
relatively finer-grained succession characterized
by the inter-fingering of the axial river system,
in the west, and the transverse river system in
the east of the rift. There is clear evidence,
particularly in the transverse system, to demon-
strate the increased proportion of mud lenses in
higher parts of the succession. This style of
preservation may have arisen as a result of cli-
matic controls leading to distinct temporal
changes in fluvial discharge regime, or subsi-
dence rates, or to a combination of both.

DISCUSSION

The study of the early-rift succession docu-
ments a coarse-grained fluvial system that flo-
wed transverse to the elongate basin axis
towards an inferred depocentre that developed
in response to progressive movement on a main
basin-bounding fault. The radial pattern of this
system supports its interpretation as a fluvial
fan (i.e. a distributive fluvial system) that
originated close to the eastern margin of the
basin and flowed towards the main depocentre
in the west. The succession probably records
the distal (fluvial-dominated) part of one or a
series of alluvial fans, which originated close
to the eastern border of the evolving basin.
This system is interpreted to have evolved into
the younger transverse system, and the finer-
grained characteristic of this younger system
might indicate that the basin was widening in
an orientation perpendicular to its axis
(Fis. r8).

Geological mapping of depositional units of
the early- to climax-rift stage confirms that the
axial fluvial succession represents a major trunk
river system and that the transverse/contributory
system developed contemporaneously to this,
as demonstrated by the lateral inter-fingering
relation of these successions. The contributory
system not only supplied the axial fluvial sys-
tem with additional sediment supply, but also
confined it to the western region of the basin.
Moreover, the western margin debris-flow-domi-
nated alluvial fans also forced the axial system
basinward, but probably exerted a minor influ-
ence compared to that of the eastern-margin
fans. This situation resulted in the axial fluvial
system being confined by debris-flow-dominated
alluvial fans to the west and fluvial-dominated
fans to the east. This relation may have been
characterized by lateral erosion due to toe-cut-
ting (cf, Leeder & Mack, 2001) which could be

controlled by a combination of tectonic or cli-

The main sedimentological differences
between these two coeval systems most probably
arose as a function of the different geomorpho-
logical and basin settings that they occupied,
which resulted in the adoption of different
drainage patterns in the same regional basin
setting (Fig. 19). Discharge was apparently
greater and more consistent in the main axial
trunk river, as demonstrated by the preserved
depositional architecture and set and coset
dimensions. This is also supported by the pres-
eryation of compound bars, built by successive
flood events, each promoting the accretion of
additional sediment in the same macroforms
(Allen, 1983), Accommodation space also played
an important role in controlling the preserved

sedimentary architecture: the axial system,
which was located close to the main basin-
bounding fault, probably experienced greater
rates of accommodation creation due to higher
rates of subsidence. By contrast, accumulation of
the transverse system, which developed on the
hangingwall and originated at the eastem basin
margin, was probably limited by a relatively slow
rate of generation of accommodation, meaning
that the transverse fluvial system was more prob-
ably to undertake progradation and to adopt a
distributive form (Nichols & Fisher, 2007). This
alone could potentially account for the difference
in preserved fluvial style,

system occurred as a result of incremental bar
growth during episodes of high-stage flow, a
diagnostic indicator for continuous and

aggrading river system bounded laterally by the

The transverse, distributive fluvial system,
which evolved as a contributory system to the
main axial river system, is characterized by an
abundance of scour surfaces, an amalgamation
of forms and sedimentary structures indicative
of upper-flow regime conditions. The existence
of scarce ponds demonstrated by rare preserva-
tion of mud drapes and lenses of mudstone
(some with preserved cracks) may indicate the
development of a floodplain with lateral and

associated minor channels that were active only
during peak floods (Bristow, 1993; Tirsgaard &
Øxnevad, 199s). Increased rates of channel
avulsion due to the presence of non-stabilized
banks may also explain the occurrences of mud
drapes, which would be deposited after minor-
channel abandonment (Tirsgaard & Øxnevad,
1998). Some of these mud deposits wete
reworked, as revealed by the local presence of
intraformational mud flakes, probably in
response to the cutting of new channels in the
immediate aftermath of avulsion events (cf. Steel
& Thompson, 1983; Cain & Mountney, 2009).
These results collectively indicate considerable
discharge variation. The downslope gradient of
this contributory river system was probably
greater than that of the trunk river, given that
the former flowed from one active basin border
in the east across the hangingwall, which was
tilting down to the west. As a consequence, dur-
ing peak precipitation, this relatively high-gradi-
ent area would be subject to substantial
discharge variation; floods would be more easily

drained in comparison to those affecting the
axial system. An aerially limited region of
hydraulic catchment, as revealed by provenance
analysis, may also have contributed to a higher
discharge variation than that of the axial system
with its regional catchment area (cf. Walling &
Moorehead, 1989; Orton & Reading, 1993), lead-
ing to decreased flow during drier seasons in the
transverse system.

Despite the absence of vegetation cover, the
studied fluvial systems were apparently able to
develop long-lived, major channelized networks.
The basin-wide extent of this pre-vegetation
fluvial system has allowed the recognition of
particularities of the depositional architecture of
a Cambrian axial river that was laterally con-
fined by both fault-scarp and bajada deposits;
this recognition is important for the study of
pre-vegetation fluvial systems. Importantly, this
tectonic setting, together with the contempora-
neous deposition of two distinct fluvial systems,
may have induced the incision of fluvial streams
into younger deposits, and systems recording

long-lived channels. These results agree with
previous models suggesting that pre-Silurian flu-
vial successions developed wide channels (e.g.
Cotter, 1978; Davies & Gibling, 2O7O). However,
it may be that the recognition of the actual styles
and particularities of such wide-channel systems
can only be achieved through basin-scale stud-
ies; this may be particularly difficult for most
mainstream preserved river successions, which
developed in cratonic settings and consequently
are characterized by much less system variabil-
ity. The presence of demonstrably channelized
macroforms led Santos et al. (2O1,2) to interpret
the axial fluvial system herein described as a
channel-braided fluvial system, although it was
not possible to determine the actual width-to-
depth ratio as an outcome of their study. A
considerable body of published work (e.g. Hjell-
bakk, 7997; Sønderholm & Tirsgaard, 1998;
Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998; Long, 2006), together
with the findings of this study, demonstrates that
pre-vegetation fluvial systems can indeed
preserve varied depositional architectures in

response to different tectonic, geomorphic and
climatic settings. It is plausible to suggest that
the laterally extensive genetic units grouped by
Cotter (1978) in the term 'sheet-braided' may in
fact encompass a series of different styles of pre-
vegetation fluvial systems; the lack of vegetation
propitiated such laterally extensive channel
forms to develop a varied number of possible flu-
vial styles and these were controlled by tectonic
and palaeoenvironmental settings.

The paucity of mud in the systems described
here probably relates to the particular charac-
teristics of this basin, which was a hydrologi
cally open system. The axial fluvial system
continuously removed finer-grained sediments
to distal areas beyond the confines of the
basin, via the downstream bypass of fine-
grained sediment (Winston, 7978; Eriksson
et al., 2OO6), Alternatively, mud deposits may
have experienced repeated deflation (Dalrymple
e¿ a1., 1985). An increased occunence of bed-
load streams would also have been promoted
by the absence of vegetation cover, with little

would be transported in suspension and
bypassed downstream. The open-system charac-
teristics of the Camaquã basin probably contrib-
uted to such bypass. Alternatively, the low
proportion of mud in this system might be a
result of slower rates of chemical weathering
as a result of the absence of deep-penetrating
plant-root systems (Long, 2OO4). However,
where and when suitable conditions for accu-
mulation occurred, mud did accumulate locally
and was preserved in abandoned channels and
incipient floodplains.

CONCLUSIONS

Three fluvial styles have been recognized in the
Guarda Velha Formation (Cambrian, southern
Brazil) through detailed analysis of lithofacies,
depositional architecture, palaeocurrent data
and pebble-provenance studies, The lowermost
(oldest) recognized fluvial system is related to
the initial subsidence of the area during an early
stage of rift-basin development and is character-
ized by conglomeratic braided channels and bars
in an arrangement indicative of a distributive
fluvial system. The two overlying fluvial systems

accumulated coevally but are differentiated on
the basis of each having distinct morphological
and architectural characteristics, and differing
relations to the local tectonic basin setting. One
of these systems can demonstrably be shown to
be the preserved succession of a perennial major
trunk river, with preserved lithofacies and archi-
tectural elements indicative of braided channels
and associated longitudinal bars that underwent
both lateral and downstream accretion. The
other system is distinguished mostly by the
preservation of deposits indicative of repeated
(and probably frequent) high discharge variation
and is indicative of a perennial distributive flu-
vial system aligned transverse to the basin axis
that flowed towards and contributed to the
major trunk river. Both of these fluvial systems
apparently evolved coevally throughout the cli-
max rift-stage and both are interpreted as peren-
nial fluvial streams, despite probably
experiencing considerable differences in total
discharge and its variability (particularly in the
transverse fluvial system). The identification of
two distinct, perennial fluvial systems fed by
two different source areas, with one of these sys-
tems - the transverse river system - having been
fed by a relatively local source area (indicated
by sources located in the eastern basin margin),

suggests a regional semi-humid to humid palae-
oclimate for the regional depositional setting.

Although several aspects of the behaviour and
preserved architectural style of pre-vegetation
fluvial deposits are known to mimic those of
modern-day arid fluvial systems, the Guarda
Velha Formation demonstrates that simulta-
neous deposition of different facies assemblages
in a pre-vegetation fluvial plain can give rise to
apparently contrasting interpretations of the
external controls on deposition. This may be the
case where different parts of the fluvial plain are
fed by distinct catchment areas and are located
in different positions in relation to the basin
axis, resulting in different patterns of discharge
variation occurring simultaneously in the axial
river system and its contributory system. Diffe-
rent rates of subsidence and accommodation
generation controlled by tectonic basin setting
probably served as a primary control on the
preservation of the different depositional archi-
tectures.

The succession preserves a great variety of
types of bedform elements, many nested
hierarchically within channelized elements.
Despite the absence of vegetation cover, the
fluvial systems discussed here were able to
develop long-lived, major channelized networks;
this is different from many Cambrian fluvial
systems interpreted in the literature as sheet-
braided styles (e.g. Todd & Went, 1991; Davies
et al., 2o1\), although those were preserved in
different tectonic settings (cratonic basins).
Other Cambrian fluvial systems in the literature,
such as the Rozel Conglomerate Formation from
the British Channel Islands (Went, 2005), were
also able to develop channelized elements.

Apparently, to date, the Guarda Velha Forma-
tion is the only example in the literature docu-
menting the preservation of the inter-fingering
relation of pre-vegetation axial and transverse
systems. The preservation of such varied fluvial
styles characterized by channel elements with
high width-to-depth ratios similar to those
described for 'sheet-braided' styles (e.g. Cotter,
1978; Davies et al., 2011) was probably deter-
mined by the tectonic context (i.e. rift basin),
demonstrating that new studies on pre-Silurian
deposits can still provide valuable information
for discussions regarding the form of the land-
scape on the continents prior to land-plant colo-
nization. These results collectively suggest that
the 'sheet-braided' fluvial style encompasses a
varied number of pre-vegetation fluvial styles,
each with distinct preserved architectures char-
acterized by channel elements which exhibit
high width to depth ratios. In this way, the pres-
ent authors propose that the term 'sheet-braided'
should be expanded in order to contain a num-
ber of different sub-groups containing distinct
pre-vegetation fluvial styles.

Existing facies models for pre-vegetation
fluvial systems are not necessarily effective in
accounting for climate and palaeoenvironmental
controls. Resolution of climate and environmen-
tal signatures for these kinds of fluvial systems
is not straightforward, and must consider spatial
variation of depositional architecture and
relation to palaeocurrent and provenance data.
Pre-vegetation fluvial systems can be as complex
as many present-day fluvial systems, despite the
absence of vegetation cover. This work has
applied implications, including the develop-
ment of more sophisticated predictive deposi-

Seismites as a tool in the palaeoenvironmental reconstruction of fluvial deposits:
The Cambrian Guarda Velha Formation, southern Brazil

Maurício G.M. Santos "'b'*, Renato P. Almeida ", Nigel P. Mountney 
b, Antonio R.S. Fragoso-Cesar a

a Inst¡tute ol Geoscíences, Un¡vers¡ty oI São Paulo, Rua do Lago. 562, Cidode Universitário, São Poulo, SP, CEP 05508-080, ùaz¡l

ARTICLE INFO ABSTRACT

Soft-sediment deformation (SSD) is widely described in the litemture, but there is no clear consensus regard-
ing its or¡gin and significance. Existing models for SSD in fluvial sediments do not clearly demonstrate a rc-
lationship between the structures, preserved facies expression. and larger-scale depos¡tional architecture.
ln this study several types of SSD structures are recorded in Cambrian fluvial deposits and these occur
interbedded with undeformed strata throughout the entire stratigraphic interval. The random distribut¡on
of these features in relation to primary facies types and fluvial forms indicates that they have neither a direct
nor indirect relationship with any depositional processes or bedform type. We propose that the relationship
of SSD at the bed-set-scale to larger-scale depositional architecture, combined with tectono-stratigraphic
analysis allows the determination of both short-term fluvial hydraulic conditions in ancient stream systems,
such as the nature of the flow regime responsible for depositing ancient fluvial stream successions, and the
long-term subsidence rates, in the form ofmean recurrence interval ofthe seismic events responsible for trig-
gering the generation of SsD in tectonically active basins.

@ 2012 Elsevier B,V. AU rights reserved.

sands) are reflected in the style of deformation and in the grain fabric.
Liquefaction can be triggered by many mechanisms capable of generat-
ing pore-pressure build-up, including seismic shaking, wave passage,
ground-water movements or impacts (Allen, 1982). ltcan also be caused
by rapid deposition in combination with a high-water table (Selley,
1969; Owen, 1995: Moretti et â1., 2001).

Many authors infer the generation of SSD structures to be triggered
by'allokinetic' mechanisms, where deformation occurred in response to
kinetic energy contributed from outside the deposystem (Leeder,
1987), a commonly invoked trigger being seismic activity (related to
episodic fault motions), normally of magnitude 5 or greater and leading
to liquidization of unconsolidated sediments in tectonically active
basins (Allen and Banks, 1972; Allen, 1986; Galli, 2000). Other exam-
ples of SSD structures have been attributed to 'autokinetic' triggering-
mechanisms, where deformation occurred in response to kinetic energy
supplied from within the depositional system ([eeder, 1987), for exam-
ple by cyclic loading from vortices (Selley, 1969), from flow conditions
approaching the plane-bed phase, from pressure fluctuations of
river-flow activity or impulsive loading from-channel bank collapse
(Lowe, 1975; Røe and Hermansen,2006), from flood surges (Owen,
1987), from flash floods (Wells et al., 1993), or from frictional drag of
saturated sand (Hendry and Stauffer, 1975). Both auto- and allokinetic
triggering mechanisms occur in nature and careful sedimentological
analysis must be undertaken to discern the most likely origin of SSD.
The recognition of triggering mechanisms is best achieved through
the combined analysis of facies, identiñcation of potential triggers, and
consideration of other available criteria (Owen et al,, 201I ).

l. Introductlon

Ancient examples of soft-sediment deformation (SSD) formed in
response to tectonic activity are widely described in the literature
(Allen and Banks, 1972; Horowitz, 1982: Leeder, 1987; Obermeier,
1996; Moretti, 2000). The relationship between preserved facies
expression in thick successions characterized by occurrences ofvari-
ous types ofsoft-sediment-deformed structures present in preserved
sedimentary successions has been the subject of numerous investiga-
tions (Selley, 1969; Lowe, 1975; Allen, 1982; Owen, 1995; Moretti et
al., 1999; Røe and Hermansen, 2006; Bryant and Miall, 2010: Owen
and Moretti, 2011; Owen et al., 2011).

SSD structures typically develop in shallowly buried, unconsolidated,
water-saturated sediments. They form when a deformation mechanism
reduces sediment strength and driving forces from the depositional
environment or from the sediment column induce deformation; distinct
combinations of such mechanisms and forces result in varied geometry
of structures (Owen, 1987). Driving forces are defined as a physical
system responsible for deformation, and relate to stresses such as grav-
itational body force (which may derive ftom the uneven distribution of
loads), unstable density gradients, and shear forces (Owen, I 987). These
forces are reflected in the geometry of deformation (Owen, 1987).
Deformation mechanisms (i.e. liquefaction and/or fluidization in

No previous studies have considered the relationship ofSSD at the
bed-set-scale to larger-scale depositional architecture in fluvial suc-
cessions. Abundant syn-sedimentary ssD structures are present at
multiple horizons in the fluvial deposits of the Guarda Velha Forma-
tion (Cambrian, southern Brazil) and here we correlate their occur-
rence with lithofacies in immediately overlying and underlying
bed-sets, and also to larger-scale trends in depositional architecture.
These relationships enable evaluation of the timing and mode of gen-
eration of the deformation structures in relation to the wider deposi-
tional and tectonic setting, and the hydrological regime ofthe basin in
which they accumulated,

The aim ofthis paper is to investigate SSD structures and their re-
lationship to facies and architectural elements in order to reconstruct
palaeoenvironmental characteristics operating during the deposition
of the Guarda Velha Formation. Results demonstrate that analysis of
SSD can be a useful tool for inferring prevailing conditions in fluvial
palaeoenvironments. A particular aim is to provide a tool for the
rccognition of activity or inactivity of river flow in pre-vegetat¡on
(i.e. pre-Silurian) fluviat systems, which lack modern-day analogs
and for which specific techniques to account for the interplay of cli-
mate and depositional sett¡ngs are not available (Long, 2006). Depo-
sitional models for pre-vegetation fluvial successions are not yet
sufficiently developed to an extent whereby they can be used to
fully account for the origin of preserved fluvial architectures (Long,
2012). A common technique in fluvial sedimentology (Miall, 1996)
is to interpret preserved deposits through process-based and facies
models that have been developed in large-part from our understand-
ing of present-day river systems. However, there are no modern flu-
vial systems that are directly analogous to pre-vegetation fìuvial
successions; the absence ofvegetation in Pre-silurian fluvial systems
apparently resulted in the accumulation of sedimentary successions
that in many ways resemble those of the present-day river systems
developed under the influence of an arid or semi-arid climate (Long,
2006), despite such successions yielding no direct evidence for such
climatic conditions.

2. Geological setting

The Camaquã Basin in southern Brazil includes >10,000 m of
siliciclastic and volcanogenic deposits of 610-530 Ma (Almeida et
al., 2010), The Camaquã Supergroup (Fragoso-Cesar et al., 2003) re-
cords the main tectonic and sedimentation events that affected the
region from the Ediacaran to the Cambrian (Fragoso-Cesar et al.,
2003; Janikian et al., 2008), and is preserved in blocks bounded by
high-angle brittle faults (Almeida et al., 2012). The Guariras Group
(Almeida et al., 2009) was deposited during the last basin-forming
extensional event, with a NW-SE-oriented minimum stress axis
(Almeida et al., 2012). The group includes > 1500 m of alluvial strata,
deposited in a 50 km-wide, 120 km-long tectonic depression, and is
separated from the underlying basement by an angular unconformity.
The Guaritas Group is equivalent to the Guaritas Allogroup of Paim
(1995) and Paim et al. (2000).

The Cambrian Guarda Velha Formation (Ribeiro, 1970: Fragoso-
Cesar, 1991; Almeida et a1.,2009, Fig. I ), is the basal unit of the Guaritas
Group (Almeida et al., 2009) and comprises a > 500 m-thick fluvial suc-
cession that accumulated from the early to climax stages of the Guaritas
Rift (Fragoso-Cesar, 1991; Paim, 1995). This succession records the de-
posits and sedimentary architecture of perennial fluvial systems devel-
oped in a Cambrian rift basin that developed in a wet to semi-wet
climatic setting, The basal part of the succession (50 to 100 m{hick,
early-rift fluvial deposits) is dominated by cobble conglomerates depos-
ited by the river-dominated part of a fluvial-fan, palaeocurrents of
which indicate a flow direction transverse to the basin axis, in a distrib-
utive pattern. Upper and thicker deposits (>400 m-thick, climax-rift
fluvial deposits) are characterized by two different fluvial associations:
(i) a perennial, axially-directed, channel-braided fluvial system (axial

(Marconato et al., 2009). These alluvial fan deposits are laterally-
related and in a few places present a lateral contact relationship with
the Guarda Velha Formation.

3. Deposltional architecture and facies analysls of the cuarda
Velha Formation

The Guarda Velha Formation deposits are predominantly sandy to
conglomeratic with abundant internal erosional surfaces, only scarce
preservation of mudstone, and rare intraformational mud-chips. The suc-
cession is dominated by sets with trough and planar cross-stratification,
alternating with laterally-extensive sets with plane-parallel bedding. lm-
bricated cobble conglomerates are restricted to the early-rift successions,
whereas fine-grained deposits, including laminated siltstone and mud-
stone are restricted to the uppennost, climax-rift successions, indicating
an overall fining-upward grain-size trend (Fig.2). Recognized lithofacies
and depositional architectural elements are presented in Table 

.l 
and an

interpreted depositional model is depicted in Fig. 3.
While the axial river deposits preserve a coarse and relatively homo-

geneous lithology composed predominantly of cross-stratified and
plane-parallel pebbly sandstones and cobble conglomerates, the trans-
verse river deposits preserve a finer-grained and relatively well-sorted
succession of medium- to pebbly-sandstones, with sparsely distributed

mud-lenses and mud-chips. The axial system is supplied by an exotic
source to the north of the basin, and reworks the transverse system de-
posits resulting in an overall bypass of the fines. SSD structures are ob-
served only in the climax-rift succession, and are more common in the
transverse fluvial system.

Preserved fluvial architecture is characterized by sandy bedforms
and laminated sandstone sheets, with lateral- and downstream-
accretion macroforms (Miall, 1996) occurring locally (Table 1).
Abandoned-channel elements are rare and those observed tend to
be draped by mudstone lenses representing ponds developed in
these channels. Sheetlike elements composed of overbank fines are
rare but, where present, occur atop the channel macroforms, with
preservation potential likely having been enhanced by channel-
avulsion (Miall, 1996). Possible overbank-fine elements are 0.2 to

0.8 m thick, and contain no evidence of pedogenesis. Only rarely do
these elements contain desiccation cracks. Overbank fines and
abandoned channel-fills occur only in the transverse fluvial system.
Fifth-order surfaces and small- and large-scale scour-and-fill struc-
tures are recognized; channel macroforms are typically wider than
outcrop width, but in some instances complete elements ranging
from 200 to 400 m wide are exposed.

planar cross-stratined; fine- to medium-grained, formerly parallel-

nally contained climbing ripple cross-lamination. In some deformed
pebbly-sandstones, pebbles have been rotated and have sunk selective-

events in a 520 m-long core; the frequency ofsuch events is higher in
the upper part of the succession, and no regular spacing between dis-
tinct events is evident.

Many types of soft-sediment folds are recognized, including eye-
shaped folds (Fig. 4B), disharmonic folds (Fig. 5B), and recumbent-
folded cross-stratiñcation with axial planes parallel or nearly parallel to
bounding surfaces (Fig. 4A). Other types of deformation structures in-
clude synclines, anticlines (Fig. 5C), dewatering pipes (Fig. 6A), and
cusps (Fig. 68). Some liquefaction events affected only one set, with
bounding surfaces undeformed (Figs.4A, B, 6A). In contrast, other events
deformed a stacked series ofcosets (Figs. 58, C, 7). Distinct styles ofdefor-
mation were observed in different bedforms. Deformation of trough
cross-stratification has led to the development ofanticlines and synclines,
recumbent-folds, disharmonic folds, and ruptured stratification. Horizon-
tal bedding is typically modified in the form of anticlines, synclines, and
clastic dykes; deformation of climbing-ripple cross-lamination typically
has a massive appearance.

The thickness of individual deformed units is from 0.1 m to more
than 1.5 m. Lateral continuity is commonly interrupted by erosional
surfaces, where later scours cut out the deposits, although some lateÍ-
ally extensive examples of deformation exceed outcrop width
(>70 m). Some liquefaction features vary laterally, passing from
current-shear drag deformation structures to disharmonic folds and
dewatering pipes related to associated fluidization (Fig. 7). These

fluidization structures occur only locally, most commonly as sand-
in-sand dykes (30 to 80 mm wide and 50 to 100 mm high), and
only rarely do they cut more than one or two bed-sets.

Most ofthe SSD bed-sets are directly overlain by erosively-based
sets and cosets ofnon-deformed strata (Figs.4,6). Although SSD oc-
curs in all types of architectural elements, there are also examples
of each architectural element with no deformational features,

5. Discussion

5.1. Depositional setting

The climax-rift palaeogeography of the Guarda Velha Formation is
interpreted as a hemi-graben in which an axially-directed, perennial
braided-river of large-scale, amalgamated bars flowed next to the
main depositional fault to the W, and a transverse-directed, distribu-
tive river system flowed from the eastern border in the direction of
the axial system. The transverse river system represents rypical
bajada deposits and was contributory to the axial system. The Guårda
Velha Formation succession is interpreted as the product of interac-
tion between two perennial, bedload-dominated, channel-braided
fluvial systems, which underwent distinct variations in river-flow dis-
charge, Discharge variation was higher in the transverse river-system,
as recorded by the alternation between cosets of trough cross-
stratification and sets of horizontal lamination (Fig. 7); nonetheless,
this transverse system preserves little evidence offlow cessation dur-
ing deposition. The presence ofa predominantly sandy to conglomer-
atic grain-size fraction, an abundance of internal erosional surfaces,
only scarce preservation of mudstone and rare intraformational
mud-chips collectively indicates that the rate of sediment supply
was greater than the rate of accommodation generation and that
the basin therefore developed in an overfilled state (Miall, 1990).

Depositional architecture in the Guarda Velha Formation is typi-
cally organized into 1 to 20 meter-thick cycles, each beginning with
an erosional scour, overlain by sandy bedforms, and passing upward
to laminated sand sheets (Fig.7) and rarely to overbank fines. Pre-
served cycles ofthis type are typical offluvial systems that underwent
marked variations in discharge, or progressive infilling of a channel
due to a rapid rate of sediment aggradation, passing repeatedly be-
tween conditions responsible for generation of lower- and upper-
flow regime bedforms (Fielding, 2006), The amalgamation of forms
resembles proximal parts of distributary fluvial systems where chan-
nel avulsion is common and frequent (Nichols and Fisher, 2007), Al-
though most of the channel macroforms are highly amalgamated,
flow in both described fluvial systems apparently developed in wide
channels; this is suggested by the presence of many fifth-order sur-
faces and large-scale scour-and-fill channels. The rare occurrence of
mud bodies, absence ofpreserved aeolian sets, and sparse occurrence
of low-flow-regime bedsets collectively indicate a semi-perennial to
perennial hydrological regime.

5.2. D eformation sfructures

SSD structures can be interpreted through comparison with simi-
lar structures generated under laboratory conditions in other studies
(Owen, 1996; Moretti et al., 1999). These experiments demonstrate
that the geometry of deformation structures is controlled by the pri-
mary structures and the driving forces, but is independent ofthe trig-
gering mechanism.

Disharmonic folds are most likely generated by gravitationally un-
stable density gradients, whereas synclines and anticlines are related
to deformation driven by vertical shear (Owen, lg96). Deformation
driven by gravitational instabilities routinely occurs after seismic
shocks and liquefaction (Moretti et al., 1999). Some features in the
Guarda Velha Formation are the result of liquefaction concomitant
with river activity: recumbent-folded cross-strata are generated by

combined flow shearing and liquidization of water-saturated sedi-

Trough cross-strata present deformation related to current-shear
drag and/or dune-collapse, resulting in non-harmonic folding and
water-escape structures. Planar cross-strata present recumbent fold-
ing related to current-shear drag. Plane-parallel strata deform mostly
in anticlines and synclines, probably as a result ofthe presence of per-
meability barriers in this type of bedding. Deformed climbing-ripple
cross-lamination loses lamination and presents a massive character
due to the loss of lamination contrast.

5.3. Trigge ring mechanisms

The Guarda Velha Formation contains SSD-bedsets developed in a
variety of primary facies types that originally accumulated in re-
sponse to lower flow-regime conditions (e.g., large-scale trough
cross-stratification), including subcritical flow (e.g., climbing ripple
cross-lamination), and upper flow-regime conditions (e.g., primary
current lineation). Undeformed sets lying immediately above de-
formed sets and possessing erosive basal surfaces post-date liquefac-
tion events, and show clear time-relationships between strata
(Figs. 3, 4, 6A). The intercalation of overturned cross-sets and
undeformed cross-stratified bedforms shows that the deformed stra-
ta were near the sediment-water interface when liquefaction oc-
curred (Fig. 8). Moreover, sedimentation continued shortly after
deformation events and such events were separated by episodes of
fluvial sedimentation presenting the same flow characteristics re-
sponsible for the deposition of the deformed strata, but preserved in
an undeformed state with no SSD structures (Fig. 8). These relation-
ships demonstrate that there is no direct causative link between flu-
vial process and SSD. Autokinetic triggering mechanisms are

process-related and, in thís way, imply a direct relation between the
morphology of the deformation structure and the nature of the
SSD-hosting medium and surrounding facies assemblages.

sSD occurrence in the Guarda Velha Formation is independent of
host or surrounding lithofacies type or architectural-element type
(e.9., channel, levee or splay), and its distribution is apparently ran-
dom throughout the succession (Fig. 2). This further suggests that de-
formation was not directly or exclusively linked to any specific set of
depositional processes or conditions that prevailed at the time ofgen-
eration. This is supported by the presence of sections with very simi-
lar facies associations and very similar bed-set scale, some of which
are deformed but others of which lack SSD. Significantly, this whole
range of flow conditions w¡thout any direct relationship to observed
SSD excludes the possibility of an autogenic triggering mechanism
(Owen and Moretti, 201 I ), and an allokinetic trigger is a more plausi-
ble explanation for the origin of the deformation structures.

The proximity of the studied deposits to major syn-depositional
active faults only 2 to l0 km to the west supports a seismic-
triggering (i.e., earthquake-induced) mechanism as the only plausible
allokinetic triggering mechanism. Additional evidence to support a
seismic origin for the structures includes the nearby presence of
fault-scarp-derived alluvial fans and talus aprons (Almeida et al.,
2009). Furthermore, fluvial deposits ofthe younger Serra do Apertado
Formation of the thermal-subsidence-induced post-rift stage of the
Guaritas Group, which accumulated after a cessation of seismic activ-
ity (Almeida et al., 2009), present the same facies association and de-
positional architecture but lacks SSD structures. Conversely, rift-
climax deposits record the nature of sedimentation at the time of
the maximum rate of fault-displacement (Prosser, 1993), and associ-
ated heightened seismic activity. The SSD bed-sets can therefore be
shown to be seismites developed in the syn-rift setting of the Guarda

Fig. 2 shows that liquefaction events occurred at a higher frequen-
cy in the upper strata of the Guarda Velha Formation. The coerse-
grained, basal succession may have been subjected to similar levels
of seismic activity, but the lithology was not particularly prone to liq-
uefaction, However, the finer-grained upper succession clearly re-
cords contemporaneous seismic activity in the numerous preserved
liquefaction horizons.

5.4. Palaeoenvironmental signifcance of SSD and relevance to pre-
v e getation riv er sy s tems

The lack of run-off control in the pre-vegetation world may have
caused short-term high discharge peaks in the drainage basin, inducing
turbulent patterns and pressure fluctuations (cf. Røe and Hermansen,
2006) that may have triggered sediment deformation. However, analy-
sis ofthe studied succession indicates that deformation occured in stra-
ta produced by a broad range of fluvial discharge regimes, including
both low-flow and high-flow stages, and SSD has no direct relationship
to particular flow conditions. Moreover, water-escape features related
to groundwater upwelling are rare and of small scale, suggesting that
water table was constantly near or above the depositional surface.
Cross-referencing between the occurrence of seismites and preserved
facies reveals that most of the liquidization events occurred at times
of active flow of the river system, a situation that would be extremely

unlikely if flow within the river system was ephemeral. Thus, SSD can
be used to infer river-flow activity, determination of which is never
straightforward, especially when applied to pre-vegetation fluvial sys-
tems. Apparent similarity in terms of facies architecture of perennial,
pre-vegetation (i.e., pre-Silurian) fluvial systems with modern ephem-
eral braided-rivers may be due to the impact of high-variability dis-
charge events caused by the absence of land plants that would have
otherwise acted to significantly stabilize the sandy substrate, reduce
channel mobility (Davies and Gibling, 2010), and subdue run-off
(Schumm, 1968), thereby dampening flood magnitude and the rate of
rise to peak discharge.

6. Conclusions

Analysis of SSD structures here identified as seismites in fluvial sed-
imentary successions, combined with the assessment of their occur-
rence in relation to primary lithofacies and depositional architecture,
permits the recognition of certain palaeoenvironmental characteristics
ofancient depositional systems, Seismic event recurrence can be evalu-
ated from recognition of the intercalation of soft-sediment-deformed
and non-deformed horizons; river-flow activity can be evaluated
through the recognition of occurrences of multiple horizons presenting
seism¡tes related to current-shear drag, The present data reveal an

increasing occurrence of seismic events throughout the deposition of
the Guarda Velha Formation. Furthermore, the data indicate perennial
flow.

This integration of tectono-stratigraphic data from seismite-
bearing fluvial successions is a useful tool for the reconstruction of
processes operating in fluvial sedimentary environments, Through
the recognition of recurrent seismic activity, variations in water-
table level, bedform morphology, and time relationships between dif-
ferent stratal units, important environmental information can be
revealed regarding fluvial depositional dynamics. This combined in-
terpretation of depositional processes and penecontemporaneous

seismites, where present, can be an important methodology in the re-
construction of fluvial-system-state, particularly in pre-vegetation
fluvial systems, which lack modern analogs and share many sedimen-
tological characteristics of modern ephemeral rivers, regardless of
their actual flow regime,

113 CAPITULO 5. TORRIDONIAN

sinuous; the role of the lack of vegetation is to reduce the likelihood of mud forming and

being retained in the river system, so the influence of vegetation on river style is indirect

rather than direct.

Soft-sediment deformation structures in the Applecross Formation are abundant,

complex and affect intervals up to 10 m thick. Most are associated with vertical
displacements of fluid and sediment. They can be classified into one of 3 styles that relate

to mode of deformation, likely trigger, and timing of deformation relative to sedimentation.

We attril-rute the 3 styles to diffelent triggers: fluid tulbulence associated with rapid

sedimentation during flood events; seismic shocks; and groundwater movements, perhaps

artesian springs at fan toes. Most of the soft-sediment deformation occurred on
inactive parts of the river system where water tables remained high. The abundance

of vertically directed soft-sediment deformation structures that formed in response
to groundwater movements supports alluvial-fan or bajada-like models for Applecross

Formation palaeoenvironments and allows the recognition of overbank ("floodplain")

environments in sheet-braided fluvial systems that pre-date the extensive development

of land vegetation. The scarcity of mud and absence of binding roots in a humid, pr€-

vegetation fluvial system may help to explain the abundance of soft-sediment deformation

in the Torridonian, due to rapid runoff and infiltration rates in the absence of vegetation.

These results illustrate the value of soft-sediment deformation structures as a tool in

the reconstruction of fluvial palaeoenvironments, particularly when integrated with the

study of fluvial sedimentology.

study form a contribution to an
ongoing Ph.D. dissertation thesis
undertaken by Mauricio G.M. Santog

land plants meant that there were no
significant biogenic agents capable of
controlling and modenting run-off or
sewing to aid bank stabilization, to
retain fine-grained sediment$ and to

publications on pre-\egetation and

whereas few studies have to-date

Fralick €t Zaniewski, 2012). The

through detailed study to which level
the assertions proposed by many
workers (e.9. Schumm, 1968; Cotter,
1978; Davies tt Gibling, 2010) that
vegetation caused a worldwide major
impact over fluvial sedimentation from
the Devonian onwards (e.9. increasing
occurrence of meandering riven, of
thick heterolithic succession, and of
pedogenic calcrete horizons, as well as
greater abundance of mudrock).
Fieldwork study has been undertaken in
NE Scotland to investigate the Silurian-
to-Early Carboniferous 0ld Red
Sandstone in the Midland Valley, where
the most complete rccord of early
sedimentation from the ORS crops out,
allowing access to a relatively
continuous and thick succession, which
is one of the most appropriate in the
world with which to develop an
undentanding of the interplay between
early land plants and fluvial
sedimentation. ìVlost previous studies of
the ORS have focused on channel-fill
elements (Davidson Êt Hartley, 2010),
whereas few works have explored the
depositional architecture of fl oodplain
elements. The increasing occurrence of
calcrcte horizons throughout the ORS
can be linked to changes in types of
vegetation cover and styles ofbiogenic
weathering by lower plants and
microbes (Wright et al., 1993), thus
representing one of the first records of
the interplay between life, climate and
continental sedimentation in the rock
record. The research presented here
investigates how fl oodplain intervals
preserved in this succession vary from
the earlier Silurian part - prior to the
evolution of higher land plants - to the
Early Carboniferous part.

The results contribute to a better
understanding of the main controls
on landscape evolution during the early
phases of land colonization by
vegetation, a key question in my PhD

Aprit 2013

thesis. ln this way, this study will
improve our abiìity to recognize
sedimentary re- sponse to climate
variation in pre-vegetation
environments, through the
undentanding of the progressive impact
of vegetation over continental
sedimentation, from the very prim- itive
forms of land plants in the Silurian
through the evolved Carboniferous
vegetation. Finally, the understanding of
such impact$ or their absence, can be
used to better un- dentand and predict
possible variations in reservoir geometry
of Precambrian and Early Palaeozoic
sequences.

Methods

The following methods were
employed: (l ) documentation of fluvial
depositional architecture in fl oodplain
successions through the construction of
a series of architectunl panels for the
study of fluvial facies and element
trends; (2) measurement of detailed
vertical profiles across the region to
investigate facies distributions in
preserved fl oodpìain elements, thereby
identifoing the reìationship of palaeosols
and rooted horizons to primary
lithofacies and eìement geometries; (3)
collation of palaeocurrent data and
examination of its relationship to
depositional architecture; (+) analysis
and mapping of plant fossiìs (diversity,
abundance and style of presentation)
and preserved palaeosol horizons.

Lower Old Red Sandstone

The Middle to Upper Silurian of the
Lower Old Red Sandstone (LORS)
deposits from the Stonehaven Group
exposed around the town of Stonehaven
record the interreìationship of fluvial
sedimentation and volcanic activity.
They are characterized by trough- and
planar-cross stratified, fine- to coarse
sandstone, cross-stratified
conglomerate, rippled and laminated
siltstone, andlaminated mudstone.
Trough-cross stntified sandstones
commonly have liquidization structures
within them, including non-harmonic

folds and recumbent-folded cross-
stratification; heterolithic facies
associations of lami- nated fine-
sandstone and siltstone commonly
record ìoading structures, including pil-
lows and disrupted layers. Lava flows
are 0.5 to 2 m thick and overlying
sediments are commonly chancterized
by very-well cemented sandstone and
conglomerate, with abun- dant evidence
of re-working of clasts from the
underlying voìcanic beds having
occurred. Overbank fines are
characterized by horizontaìly-extensive,
tabular bodies, each up to 2 m-think;
lateral-extent of these bodies is
difficult to determine due to the
presence of numerous, vertical faults
that displace the stratignphy. Channels
are characterized by sandy bedforms and
laminated sandstone sheets.

The Early Devonian deposits of the
Arbroath Sandstone Member (Scone
Sandstone

Formation, Arbuthnott-Garvock
Group) are typically chancterized by
planar and trough cross-stratified
sandstone and pebbly sandstone, low-
angle and horizontally bedded sand-
stone, rippled cross-laminated sandstone
and siltstone, and ìaminated siltstone
and mud- stone. Depositional
architecture is mainly characterized by
sandy bedforms with asso- ciated
laminated sandsheets forming multi-
storey channel elements; abandoned-
channels are lenticular (5 to 15 m
wide) and filled by up to 0.5 m-thick
deposìts of silty mud- stone.
Overbank fines are characterized by
tabular bodies up to 2 m think and 5 to
20 m wide; these are commonly
truncated laterally and upward by upper
cosets from the sandy

bedforms. Calcrete nodules are
present at the top of overbank deposits
and abandoned channels, whereas
intraformational mudstone chips and

Aprit 20't3

sandstone clasts are common, with
abundant examples of re-worked
calcrete concretions.

Upper Old Red Sandstone

The Early Carboniferous deposits from
the Kinnesswood Formation of the
Upper Oìd Red Sandstone (UORS) are
less deformed than those of the older
studied succession, allowing a more
thoroughly understanding of the
depositionaì environments to be deter-
mined. Typical lithofacies of this
formation are low-angle incìined and
horizontal sand- stone, trough and
planar cross-stratified sandstone,
intraformational conglomerate with re-
worked cìasts of caìcrete concretion,
laminated siltstone, and laminated
mudstone. Finning-upward cycles are
common and many such cycles are
capped by a calcrete hard- pan with
preserved rootlets at their top. Rootlets
are up to 50 mm in diameter and up to
I m-long; they are found in both
muddy and sandy deposits, and are
clearly related to the calcrete horizons;
the occurrence of the latter is related to
semi-arid to arid-climatic conditions
(Wright tt Marriott, 2OO7).

Channel environments were
characterized by sandy, bed-ìoad
dominated streams, and preserved
elements of such features form
sequences of single-storey sandy
bedforms; intraformational mud chips
and sandstone clasts such as pebbìes
and cobbles of mudstone are common
at some leveìs within deposits of these
elements. Floodplain environments
were characterized by laminated fines,
and small-scale lateral-accretion
channels. Preserved fl oodplain channels
are 30 to B0 cm thick cosets of trough
and planar cross- stntification
commonly characterized by clast-
supported congìomerates of re-worked
calcrete concretions (indicating

of cosets are characterized by hardpans.

Preliminary Discusslon
Preliminary results show an increasing

incidence of occurrence of calcretes in
both the numbers of instances and
thickness (in this research, no exampìes
in the Middle Silurian, few examples in
the Middle Devonian, and prolific
examples in the Early Carboniferous),
from the LORS to the UORS, reflects not
only an increasing biological activity
(e.9. Wright et al. (1993)) activity on the
continental environment throughout the
geological time, reflected in the direct
relationship of calcretes horizons and
rootìets, but also records the
establishment of semi-arid climatic
settings in the region of the Midland
Valley, and also an obvious increasing
occurrence of rootlets (macroscopically,
this research encountered examples of
vegetation only in the Early
Carboniferous). lndeed, there is a
sudden appearance in the Carboniferous

UORS of 0.5 to 1.5 m-thick rooted
horizons: this seems to be related to
the appropriate environment of
floodplains which were abandoned for
long periods of time (as recorded by the
thick calcrete horizons), allowing
biological activityto develop.

Although vegetation was present in
the LORS, the increasing colonization of
land plants was not foììowed by an
increasing occurence of mudstone in
the Midland Valley, as would be
expected from the probable enhanced
rates of chemical weathering as a
corìsequence of such coìonization.
lndeed, there are moTe prcserved muddy
deposits in the Middle-Silurian LORS
than in the Middle Devonian LORS, and
this was probably a consequence of
environmental conditions, such as the
interaction between fl uvial systems,
nearby prcsence of volcanic activity, and
climate.

The interpìay between climatic
conditions and land plant colonization
is recorded in the successions of the
Midland Valley: Middìe-Silurian
deposits show no examples of calcrete
nodules, the Middle Devonian deposits
show localized examples of concretions
in overbank deposits as welì as re-
worked clasts of calcareous mudstone
clasts, and the Early Carboniferous ones

20



t7t lÂS Nwltr 245

show clear examples of not onþ thick
calcrcte horizons and hardpans, but also
prolific occunences of rootlets in the
fluvial realm, clearþ recording the
enhanced biological actïvio/ in the land.

Figura 8. Fotomosaico do elemento arquitetônico Enchentes em Lençol em afloramento da Formação Serra do Apedado
(coordenadas UTM E0277301 e N6585047, datum SAD69), em sua seção-tipo nos flancos da Serra do Apertado. Predominam
séries de arenito com estratificação cruzada acanalada da fácies Aa. Observa-se que as superfícies de terceira ordem são
sempre sobrepostas por camadas pelíticas da fácies Pl e sobrepÕem laminações plano-paralelas da fácies Al. Pontiralmente,
as estrat¡ficações cruzadas acanaladas da fácies Aa encontram-se convolutas (centro esquerdo da fotografia), assim como
os pelitos da fácies Pl (canto superior direito da fotografia). Ordens das superlícies segundo Miall (1996).

Figura 11. Fotomosaico do elemento arquitetônico Dunas Barcanoides em afloramento da Formação Pedra Pintada
superior, a leste das Minas do Camaquã (coordenadas Uf ME2B0212 e N6574898, datum SAD69). Predominam séries de
arenito com estratificaçoes cruzadas de grande porte da fácies Aag. Observa-se uma superfície de migração de interduna
que trunca as superfícies de superimposição, com ângulo baixo de mergulho e sentido de mergulho contrário ao das
estratificações cruzadas. Ao longo de toda a superfície de migração de interduna, ocorrem camadas com concentrados
de grânulos. Ordens das superfícies segundo Miall (1996).

Figura 12, Fotomosaico dos elementos arquitetônicos Dunas Barcanoides, abaixo, e lnterdunas Fluviais, acima,
separados por uma superfície erosiva de quarta ordem, em afloramento da Formaçao Pedra Pintada superior (coordenadas
UfM 8280212 e N6574898, datum SAD69). O elemento lnterdunas Fluviais apresenla arenitos com laminação plano-
paralela da fácies Al e estratificação cruzada acanalada da fácies Aa, com seixos e grânulos abundantes. Observa-se
que a superfície de quarta ordem que define o contato entre os elementos lnterdunas Fluviais e Dunas Barcanoides
é concordante com a superlície de migraçäo de interduna do elemento Dunas Barcanoides. Ordens das superfícies
segundo Miall (1996).
