Abstracts, 28'h IAS Meeting of Sedimentology 201 l, Zaragoza, Spain f4d. Sedimentation
in rilt basins

Fluvial deposits from early to climax rift stages:

The Guarda Velha Formation, Guaritas Group, Southern Brazil

M.G,M. Santosr, R,P. Almeidar, A. Marconator & L.P.S. Godinhol

l: lnstituto de Geociôncias, Universidade de São Paulo, 5ão Paulo, Brazil (mauricioguerreiro@yahoo.com)

An integrated study of depositional architecture, facies analysis, regional stratigraphic relationships,
palaeocurrent and provenance data from a more than 500 m thick fluvial succession of the Guar<ja Velha
Formation in the Guaritas Rift, Cambrian, Southern Brazil, reveals three different fluvial systems and
sedimentation patterns from the early to climax rifting stages: an early-rift fluvial system of braided gravel bars,

and two contemporaneous fluvialsystems from the early to climax stages, represented by a perennialaxial, trunk

fluvial system, and a tributary fluvial system presenting markedly high discharge variation and channelized forms.

The lowermost fluvial system was deposited during the early-rift initiation and is characterized by coarse-grained

sandstones deposited in braided channels and imbricated, pebble to boulder, polymictic conglomerates
deposited in large dimension, low angle gravel bars, Palaeocurrent data for this lowermost succession reveal a

basin-transverse system, and this observation is supported by provenance data pointing to sediment sources

from the east of the basin. After this initial stage, a more complex fluvial system was established during the early

to climax stages of the Guaritas Rift, comprising two distinct signatures of fluvial deposits that present different

depositional architecture styles, provenance, and palaeocurrent patterns, These point to a main trunk river
system, running near and parallel to the extensional, sin-depositional main active fault, These deposits present

large-scale bedforms of amalgamated bars with lateral and downstream accretion, revealing a basin-axial fluvial

system with provenance from distal areas to the north of the basin, Other contemporaneous fluvial system
present more varied facies, mediurn to low scale channelized bedforms, and abundant soft-sediment deformation

features. Depositional architecture is dominated mainly by sandy bedforms and larninated sand sheets, with

minor occurrence of downstream accretion, scour-fills and abandoned scours. Palaeocurrent analysis points to a

system flowing transversally to basin' axis, towards the interpreted trunk river system, revealing a tributary
system with provenance from the eastern basement. This integrated study reveals different depositional styles

developed in one same fluvial plain, a situation that, without proper stratigraphic control, could potentially lead

to misinterpretations regarding the evolution of alluvial successions and their allogenic controls. Therefore, the

effect of the size and local characteristics of distinct catchment areas may be a major control in fluvial systems of

rift basins,

The impact of early land plants on continental sedimentation: the Old Red
Sandstone in the Midland Valley (Scotland, UK)

Mauricio G. M. Santost''*, Adrian J. Hartley3, Nigel P. Mountney2 & Luca Colombera2

l lnstitute of Geosciettces, IJniversity of Sao Paulo, Brazit

2Fluviat Research Group, lJniversity of Leects, LtK

3Flttvialsysfems 
Research Group, L)nfuersfty of Aberdeen, IJK

* 
co rre s po n d i n g a u th o r : Ir a lqçlag ngrUt!_oSlq)S¡t¡jl-çA1¡

This research examines the extent to which current models are effective in accounting
for the role played by early vegetation in governing the sedimentation process, Fieldwork
undertaken in NE Scotland has investigated the Silurian to Early Carboniferous Old Red
Sandstone in the Midland Valley. The succession comprises a near-complete record of
sedimentation through the I km-thick ORS deposits, which, since it covers the main
episode of land plant colonization, is one of the most appropriate successions known
globally with which to develop an understanding of the interplay between early land-plant
evolution and fluvial sedimentation.

Although simple plants were present in the LORS, the progressive colonization of the
fluvial plain by land plants was apparently not matched by a related increase in the
occurrence of mudrock in the Midland Valley, as predicted by existing models of
weathering processes. lndeed, preservation of mud-prone deposits is more prevalent in
the Middle-Silurian LORS than in the Middle Devonian LORS, a situation interpreted
here as a conseguence of environmental conditions. The interplay between climatic
conditions and land-plant colonization is recorded by other sedimentological factors:
Middle-Silurian deposits do not preserve calcrete noclules, whereas Middle Devonian
deposits preserve localized examples of concretions in overbank deposits, as well as re-
worked clasts of calcareous mudstone; the Early Carboniferous succession (Upper
ORS) records abundant examples of calcrete horizons and hardpans, and prolific
occurrences of rootlets (rhizoliths and rhizocretions), recording the enhanced effects of
biogenic surface stabilization by this time. Results record not only increasing biogenic
control on continental sedimentation through time, but also document the establishment
of a semi-arid climatic setting in the region from the Middle Devonian to the Early
Carboniferous. This research is contributing to an improved understanding of the main
controls on landscape evolution during the early phases of land colonization by
vegetation.

Memorial Fund and the IAS Postgraduate Grant Scheme

Pre-vegetation fluvial styles in a Cambrian rift basin

M.G.M. Santosr2, R.P. Almeidar, L.P.S. Godinhor, A. Marconator and N.P. Mountney2

I Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, BRAZIL. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com
2 Fluvial Research Group, University of Leeds, England, UK.

1. lntroduction
The mechanisms by which many different types of fluvial
system undergo sedimentation and accumulation to
generate a preserved stratigraphic record are now relatively
well understood and a variety of process-based and facies
models now exist with which to account for the origin of
many preserved fl uvial sed imenta ry a rchitectures. However,

one exception to this is that of pre-vegetation (i.e. pre-
Silurian) fluvi¿l successions for which uncertainty remains
regarding the nature of the fluvial conditions required to
accumulate and preserve architectural elements in the
absence of the stabilizing infìuence of vegetation (Long,
2012). Here we present a detailed study that demonstrates
the presence of highly variable pre-vegetation stratigraphic
architectures. This study utilizes facies and architectural-
element analysis, integrated with regional stratigraphic
basin analysis, and studies of palaeocurrent and pebble
provenance data to consider the mechanisms responsible
for preserving the varied range of fluvial architectures
present in a rift-basin setting.

2. Pre-vegetation fluvial systems
ln pre-vegetation fluvial successions, the repeated re-
working of bars and minor-channels commonly resulted in

the generation and preservation of broad, tabular, stacked
sandstone sheets. Preserved channel elements commonly
present high width-to-thickness ratios typical of resultant
sheet-braided fluvial systems. This has previously been
regarded as the dominant fluvial sedimentary style prior to

the Silurian (e.9. Cotter, 1978), a situation that is closely
analogous to present-day, poorly-vegetated systems
developed in arid or semi-arid climatic settings.

3. The Guarda Velha Formation
The Guarda Velha Formation of Southern Brazil is a >500 m-

thick synrift fluvial succession of Cambrian age that records
the deposits and sedimentary architecture of three distinct
fluvial successions: (i) an early-rift stage system
characterized by transverse and distributary coarse-grained
channel elements; and two coeval systems from the early-
to climax-rift stages that represent (ii) an axially-directed,
trunk fluvial system characterized by large-scale
amalgamated sandy braid-bar elements, and (¡ii) a
transverse, distributary fluvial system characterized by
multi-storey, sandy braided-channel elements. High-
resolution architectural analyses of these deposits reveal
significant variations in geometry, with characteristics far
more complex than that of simple, laterally extensive,
stacked sandstone-sheets predicted by most existing
depositional models for pre-vegetation fluvial systems.

4. Controls on pre-vegetation fluvial styles
Several major controls on fluvìal sedimentary style are
identified in the Guarda Velha Formation and these include:
(i) spatial and temporal variation in discharge regime; (ii)
the varying sedimentological characteristics of distinct
catchment areas; (iii) the role of tectonic basin
configuration and its direct role in influencing palaeoflow
direction and fluvial style, whereby both axial and
transverse fluvial systems are recognized within a rift-basin
setting, each of which responds to syndepositional
movement on basin-bounding faults. Climatic controls are
probably present, but the recognition of such controls
demands utilization of modern analogues, which are not
available.

5. Conclusions
This study demonstrates that the preserved sedimentary
expression of pre-vegetation fluvial successions can be as
complex as that of post-vegetation fluvial successions, with

depositional architectural characteristics substantially more

complex than that of simple, laterally extensjve, stacked
sandstone-sheets, Th¡s suggests that the sheet-braided
model (i.e channels with high width-to-thickness r¿tios)
may actually encompass a varied number of different fluvial

styles, not all of which have yet been fully characterized.
Moreover, contemporaneous axial and transverse fluvial
systems with distinct preserved fluvial architectural
expressions can be preserved in the same tectonic and
climatic setting.

Palaeoenvironmental significance of soft-sediment deformation in fluvial successions:
the Neoproterozoic Applecross Formation, Torridon Group, UK
M.G.M. Santosr'2 and G. OwenJ

ì lnstituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com
r Fluvial Research Group, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, Leeds, UK.
rDepartment of Geography, Swansea University, Swansea, UK. g.owen@swansea.ac.uk

1. lntroduction
A distinctive feature of the Applecross Formation is the
prolific occurrence of soft-sediment deformation structures
that are complex in geometry and varied in scale. We present
a methodology for interpreting the significance of soft-
sediment deformation in fluvial successions based on criteria
that relate to sedimentary facics, depositional environment,
river-flow act¡vity, and position in the fluvial plain.

2. Characteristics of the Applecross Formation
The Neoproterozoic Applecross Fm of the Torridon Group,
NW Scotland, is a thick and relatively uniform fluvial
success¡on representing the deposits of large-scale fluvial
systems. The formation is characterized by medium-grained
to conglomeratic sandstones with horizontal bedding and
trough and planar cross-bcdding organized in 0.3 to 2.0 m-
scale sets and cosets, The depositional architecture is
characterized by laterally-extensive sandbodies of mainly
tabular geometry. Channel forms present high width-to-
thickness ratios typical of a sheet-braided style. Stratigraphic
markers are rare to absent. Due to the absence of land plants
covering the fluvial plain at this time, fluvial systems
experienced high rates of run-off, lacked bank stabilization,
and were subject to rapid rates of sedimentation; such
characteristics may have played a significant role in the
development and triggering of penecontemporaneous
deformation.

3. Soft-sediment deformation in the Applecross
Formation and its significance

Soft-sediment deform¿tion structures can be triggered by a
number of different mechanisms, separated by Leeder (,l987)
into allokinetic (originating outside the depos¡tional
environment, such as earthquakes and impacts) and
autokinetic (related to depositional processes, such as
current-shear drag, rapid sedimenration, and flash-floods). ln
fluvial deposits, both allokinetic (e.9. Santos et al. 2012) and
autokinetic triggers (e,9. Røe and Hermensen 2006) occur.

We have defined distinct styles of soft-sediment deformation
structures based on morphology, scale, lateral variability,
upward termination, and position of ¿n active layer. These are
a development of the assemblages defined by Owen (1995).
Style 1 Usually small-scale, laterally variable srrucrures;
complexity of deformation increases upwards and is
truncated upwards; deformation records both lateral and
vertic¿l shear. This represents localised syn- and meta-
depositional deformation triqgered by flash floods and/or
rapid scdiment loading, and driven by various forces such as
flow-induced lateral shear, bedform collapse and water

escape. This style forms in areas of intermittently active
floodplain splays.
Style 2 Laterally extensive deformation dominated by lateral
shear; complexity of deformation increases upwards and is
truncated upwards. This represents syn-depositional
deformation drive n by current shcar over a liqucfied
substrate, most likely triggered by seismic activity, although
flash floods and/or rapid sediment loading are also possihle
triggers. This style forms in active river tracts or previously
deposited, saturated floodplain splays.
Style 3 Localised and isolated deformation, commonly very
large scale, dominated by vertical shear that deforms and
disrupts adjacent strata, Th¡s represents post-depos¡tional
deformation related to fluidization originating in the
subsurface and triggered by groundwater fluctuations and/or
seismic shaking. This style forms in ¿reas of abandoned river
tracts.

4. Conclusions
This analysis demonstrates the value of soft-sediment
deformation structures in understanding the Precambrian
fluvial environment. Different styles of soft-sediment
deformation can be used as proxy indicators of different parts
of this particular fluvial system, where the absence of fine-
grained material induced the preserv¿tion of apparently
monotonous sedimentary architectures.

Meandering rivers as facilitators for the Palaeozoic land-plant evolution

M.G.M. Santosr'/, N.P. Mountneyr and J. Peakall'

I Fluvial Research Group, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, UK.
2lnstituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, BRAZIL. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com

1. lntroduct¡on
The increasing prominence of meandering fluvial channel
systems over geologic time has long been linked to land-
plant colonization during the middle Palaeozoic (Schumm,

1 968; Cotter, 1 978). This has been recently reinforced by the

observed increase from the Cambri¿n to the Devonian in
the percentage of published case studies describing fluvial
successions exhibiting facies characteristic of meandering
rivers (Davies and Gibling, 2010). Here we discuss the
nature of this relationship and propose that the apparent
sudden widespread occurrence on Earth of sedimentary
features indicative of the accumulation of meandering river

deposits in the Late Silurian and its prominent increase
throughout the Devonian was not primarily the
consequence of the evolution of land plants; rather, it was
primarily an effect of global environmental and tectonic
conditions that prevailed during the Ordovician-Devonian.

2. Meandering rivers and land plants
The role played by vegetation in progressively stabilizing
river banks, encouraging single-thread channels at the
expense of multi-thread, braided channels is argued to
have caused major environmental impact in the
continental alluvial realm from the Silurian onwards.
Paradoxically, meandering rivers are also known from pre-
vegetation successions, and spectacular high-sinuosity
examples have recently been observed on Mars. Moreover,
laboratory experiments have successfully demonstrated
that mud content alone can be sufficient to induce
meandering ch¿nnels.

lncreases in the occurrence of meandering river deposits in

the rock record occurred concurrently wìth the inception
and evolution of land plants. However, early Palaeozoic
plants had limited biomass, and were confined to lowland
and riparian habitats; arborescence developed only during
Middle- to Upper-Devonian (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998).
Plant-root networks were able to penetrate no more than
one metre-deep until the evolution of more complex land
plants in the Late Devonian. The impact of land plants as
agents for substrate stabilization and run-off retention was

therefore modest at best unt¡l the Upper-Devonian.

3. Tectonic and environmental conditions during the
Late Palaeozoic

The Ordovician to Devonian conditions in the
palaeocontinents of Baltica and Laurasia (from which the
majority of study cases have been published) included: (ì)
prolonged episodes of high eustatic sea level whereby
significant areas of the continental shelves were at or close
to sea level, leading to the development of extensive, low-
gradient coastal plains traversed by major rivers; (ii) the

Caledonian assemblage of continents leading to the
development of many large, internally-draining basins; and
(iii) the amalgamation of continental landmasses in
intertropical latitudes subject to high levels of rainfall in
climatic zones that propitialed the generatìon of a
significant volume of cohesive mud via increased rates of
chemical weathering.

4. Conclusions
This research supports the hypothesis that the above-
descnbed condrtions induced large rivers to adopt
meandering channel planforms, which in turn acted to
encourage the proliferation of land plants by providing
extensive, fertile, mud-prone floodplains, which acted as
catälysts that enabled the acceleration of land-plant
evolution and the¡r spread. Once land plant colonization
was lnitiated, plants and meandering rivers developed a
synergistic relationship, whereby plants acted as substrate-

stabilizing and soil-forming agents that resulted in a
progressive increase in the incidence of meandering river
environments.
